abstract.p: List of events tied to Operation Sail 2000 in New York during Fourth of July holiday period; photo; map (M)

block.p: Here are events tied to Operation Sail 2000:
Tomorrow
FREE WATERFRONT CONCERT, Battery Park, Great Lawn, Lower Manhattan. Featuring Billy Bragg and Shawn Colvin. 3:30 p.m. Sponsored by the Downtown Alliance. Information: (212) 835-2789.
Here are events tied to Operation Sail 2000:
Tomorrow
FREE WATERFRONT CONCERT, Battery Park, Great Lawn, Lower Manhattan. Featuring Billy Bragg and Shawn Colvin. 3:30 p.m. Sponsored by the Downtown Alliance. Information: (212) 835-2789.

TANABATA FESTIVAL: TALES FROM JAPAN, South Street Seaport Museum, Children's Center, 165 John Street, Lower Manhattan. An event with storytelling and a decoration workshop. 1 to 4 p.m. Fee, $2. Information: (212) 748-8758.
MUSIC AT THE PIERS, Chelsea Piers, Pier 62, Hudson River and 23rd Street, Manhattan. A free concert with Total Remix. Noon to 4 p.m. Information: (212) 336-6881.

U.S.O. TROUPE OF METROPOLITAN NEW YORK, Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum, Pier 86, West 46th Street and 12th Avenue. Free variety show presented most Saturdays and Sundays at 1, 2:30 and 4 p.m. (On July 8, the times are at 1, 3:30 and 5:30 p.m.) Information: (212) 245-0072.

LIBERTY STATE PARK MUSIC AND HERITAGE FESTIVAL, off Exit 14B of the New Jersey Turnpike, Jersey City. A free weekend of environmental discussions, music, exhibitions and ''open houses'' on several tall ships. 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Also Sunday, same hours. Sponsored by the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater. Information: (201) 200-2622; Web site: www. libertystatepark.com.
Sunday

FREEDOM TOUR, Museum of Jewish Heritage-A Living Memorial to the Holocaust, 18 First Place, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Focuses on Jewish immigrants' contributions to the growth of the country. Noon and 2 p.m. Also July 4, same times. Free with admission, $7; $5 for children, students and the elderly; children under 5, free. Information: (212) 509-6130.

MUSIC AT THE PIERS, Chelsea Piers, Pier 62, Hudson River and 23rd Street, Manhattan. A free concert with the Hank Williams Lonesome Cheatin' Hearts Club Band. Noon to 4 p.m. Information: (212) 336-6881.
Monday
TALL SHIPS ARRIVE at their berths in Gravesend, Brooklyn, and New Jersey.
NEW YORK POPS, World Trade Center Plaza, Lower Manhattan. The conductor Skitch Henderson leads the Pops in a free outdoor concert at 7:30 p.m. to welcome the tall ships. Information: (212) 765-7677.
Tuesday

GUN SALUTES AND A BLESSING OF THE FLEET. On the naval cruiser Hue City, starting at 8 a.m., President Clinton sails down the Hudson River to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to review the anchored warships. From there, President Clinton will transfer to the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy, anchored opposite the Statue of Liberty, for the blessing of the fleet and the Parade of Sail, scheduled to start about 10 a.m.

PARADE OF SAIL begins about 10 a.m. as the Eagle passes beneath the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. The procession then travels through the lower New York Bay, between Brooklyn and Staten Island to the Hudson River. It passes the Statue of Liberty and continues up the Hudson River to a point south of the George Washington Bridge, where the ships reverse direction and head south for berthing. The parade is expected to last about three hours.

INTERNATIONAL NAVAL REVIEW AND MILITARY FLYOVER, Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River. All participating vessels parade up the Hudson River for review by government and military leaders from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. The parade will be visible from the museum and from points along the Hudson River. A formation of military aircraft will fly over the parade route. Museum holiday hours: Tuesday-Thursday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; July 7-8, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; July 9, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. Information: (212) 245-0072.

TALL SHIPS BERTH IN NEW YORK CITY WATERS AND SHIP VISITS BEGIN. Berthing begins at about 1 p.m. with public visiting from 3 to 6 p.m. at the following piers. Class A ships: South Street Seaport, Pier 36 (South Street at Montgomery Street, north of Manhattan Bridge), Piers 86-88 (12th Avenue and 46th Street) and Piers 59-63 (Chelsea Piers, 12th Avenue and 23rd Street); in Brooklyn, the 69th Street Pier (Shore Parkway at Bay Ridge Avenue, Bay Ridge), the Port Authority Piers 7 and 8 (south of Atlantic Avenue) and piers along West Street in Greenpoint. (See map for specific Class A ships.)

Class B Ships: Pier 36, Pier A (Battery Park), South Street Seaport, 79th Street Boat Basin, Pier 40 (Houston Street), Pier 63, Pier 84 (44th Street and 12th Avenue) and Riverbank Park (Riverside Drive and 145th Street); on Staten Island, Pier 2 (adjacent to the Ferry Terminal); in New Jersey, Liberty State Park.

Class C Ships: Pier 40, Piers 63, 84, 42-45 (West Side Highway, between Morton and West 10th Streets) and Riverbank Park; in Queens, at the World's Fair Marina; in Brooklyn, the Fulton Ferry Esplanade (under Brooklyn Bridge); on Staten Island, Pier 2; in New Jersey, Stevens Institute in Hoboken along the waterfront and Lincoln Harbor in Weehawken.

OPERATION SAIL TALL SHIPS FESTIVAL, South Street Seaport Museum, South and Fulton Streets, Lower Manhattan. A good viewing spot for the tall ships parade and the fireworks. The Coast Guard band performs outdoors at noon and 7 p.m. Several tall ships will be docked at Piers 16 and 17, starting Wednesday, for boarding and touring. Information: (212) 748-8600.

FRAUNCES TAVERN MUSEUM OPEN HOUSE, 54 Pearl Street, Lower Manhattan. Screenings of historic and maritime videos. 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Donations accepted. A free outdoor fife and drum recital by the Veteran Corps of Artillery is planned at 2 p.m. A walking tour of ''George Washington's New York'' that complements the museum's ''Politics in 1800'' exhibit, begins at 3 p.m.; fee, $10. Information: (212) 425-1778.
GREAT FOURTH OF JULY FESTIVAL, Water Street, Lower Manhattan. Vendors, displays, entertainment. 10 a.m. to 11 p.m. Information: (212) 809-4900.

LIBERTY STATE PARK MUSIC AND HERITAGE FESTIVAL, Exit 14B of the New Jersey Turnpike, Jersey City. A free concert featuring the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra with Wynton Marsalis; the Louis Armstrong Legacy Band and the David Ostwald Gully Low Jazz Band. 4 to 9:30 p.m.; a fireworks display west of the Statue of Liberty will be visible from the park at about 9:50 p.m. Information: (201) 200-2622; Web site, www.libertystatepark.com.
Wednesday
BATTERY PARK PLAZA SUMMER CONCERT SERIES, 1 Battery Park Plaza. Bob Cantwell and the Stompers. 12:15 p.m. Free. Sponsored by Rudin Management Company. Information: (212) 407-2429.
TALL SHIP PUBLIC VISITS. 10 to 6 p.m. Through July 8 at piers listed above.
Thursday

MUSIC AT CASTLE CLINTON, Lower Manhattan. Average White Band. 7 p.m. Admission is free, but tickets are required and seating is first come, first served; ticket distribution begins at 5 p.m at Castle Clinton. Information: (212) 835-2789.

MILITARY SALUTE WEEK, Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum, Pier 86, West 46th Street and 12th Avenue. Featuring an arm wrestling tournament, open to men and women, at 1 p.m.; a United States Marine Corp Harrier and Pier Raid Demonstration at 2 p.m. (also July 7-8); and a search-and-rescue demonstration by the United States Coast Guard at 4 p.m. (also July 7-8). All events are free. Information: (212) 245-0072.

LIBERTY STATE PARK MUSIC AND HERITAGE FESTIVAL, Exit 14B of the New Jersey Turnpike. Appearance by the Italian tenor Andrea Bocelli. 8 p.m. Tickets, $60 to $500. Information: (201) 200-2622; or Ticketmaster, (212) 307-7171 or (201) 507-8900.
Next Friday

MILITARY SALUTE WEEK, Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum, Pier 86, West 46th Street and 12th Avenue. A parachute demonstration by the United States Army Golden Knights at noon and 5 p.m. (also July 8 at 3 p.m.); a tug-of-war tournament between branches of the military at 1 p.m.; air acrobatics by members of the United States Navy Leap Frogs Parachute Team at 3 p.m. (also July 8 at noon and 5 p.m.). Free. Information: (212) 245-0072.
July 8

MILITARY SALUTE WEEK, Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum, Pier 86, West 46th Street and 12th Avenue. A seamanship competition featuring knot-tying and a signal flag contest at noon; and a ''best chow'' competition judged by chefs from New York restaurants at 2 p.m. Admission: $12; $9 for veterans and reservists and students; $6 for children 6 to 11; $2 for children 2 to 5; free for children under 2, active military personnel and museum members. Information: (212) 245-0072.

FAREWELL JAZZ CONCERT, Central Park Bandshell, mid-park at 72d Street. In tribute to the visiting ships and crews, featuring Eric Benet and Claudia Acuna, singers, and John Scofield, guitarist. 6 to 10 p.m. Sponsored by the mayor's office and Bet on Jazz: the Jazz Channel (BET).
July 9
TALL SHIPS DEPART, starting about 10 a.m. Some will sail for New London, Conn., or Portland, Me., while others return home.
O Say Can You See: Where to Watch the Parade of Sail

The Parade of Sail will begin about 10 a.m. on Tuesday, moving from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge up the Hudson to south of the George Washington Bridge. The ships will then reverse direction and sail down the Hudson to their berths. The event is expected to last about three hours. Here is a sampling of places with a clear view of the parade:
On Land

MANHATTAN: South Ferry Terminal, Battery Park, Battery Park City Esplanade, Pier 45 (West 10th Street), Riverside Park from 56th to 72nd Streets and from 90th to 102nd Streets, Bulk Head River's Edge from 125th to 133rd Streets, Riverside Drive Viaduct, and the Riverside Park Recreation Area.

BROOKLYN: New Dock Street, Main Street, Empire State Park below the Brooklyn Bridge, the Brooklyn Heights Promenade and Esplanade, Sunset Park, Owls Head Park, 69th Street Pier and Park Promenade from Bensonhurst to Bay Ridge.

STATEN ISLAND: Richmond Terrace Esplanade, railing along Richmond Terrace (Wall Street to Nicholas Street), Bay Street, Front Street Bulkhead, Matthew Buono Beach, Fort Wadsworth and Von Briesen Park.
NEW JERSEY: Along the Hudson River in Fort Lee, Edgewater, Guttenberg, North Bergen, West New York, Weehawken, Union City, Hoboken, Jersey City and Liberty State Park.
On Television

OP SAIL 2000, NBC, Channel 4 in New York. The official television station for Op Sail 2000 begins coverage at 5 a.m. on Tuesday with ''Today New York.'' It continues with live broadcasts from 9 to 10 a.m. and again from noon to 3 p.m.; additional coverage during regular news programming at 5 and 6 p.m. (At 9 p.m. it will broadcast the Macy's Fourth of July fireworks.)

CELEBRATE FREEDOM 2000, Fox News Channel, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Live broadcasts from the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy as the ships enter the harbor. Jon Scott and Linda Vester will be the hosts. The coverage will also include taped segments with Mr. Scott on board the Polish ship Dar Mlodziezy and Ms. Vester on the naval submarine Philadelphia.

THE GREATEST AMERICAN FOURTH OF JULY, WNET, Channel 13, 9 a.m. to noon. Live broadcasts of the Parade of Sail and the International Naval Review 2000 before President Clinton, and taped segments highlighting Navy history; with Dr. William F. Baker, president of WNET, and Mark McEwen, CBS correspondent, as co-hosts.
By Sea

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, Pier 83, West 42nd Street and 12th Avenue. Two-hour cruises leave every half-hour from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Tickets: $30; $25 for the elderly; $20 for children. Forty-five-minute speedboat rides aboard ''The Beast'' depart at 10:30 and 11:45 a.m. and 1, 2:15, 3:30 and 4:45 p.m. Tickets: $15; $10 for children 5 to 12. . (A four-hour fireworks cruise begins boarding at 5 p.m. and sails from 6 to 10 p.m. Tickets: $100.) Reservations and information: 212 563-3200.

WORLD YACHT, Pier 81, West 41st Street and 12th Avenue. A three-hour cruise including a buffet lunch, piano music and a view of the Parade of Sail boards at 10:30 a.m. and sails from 11 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. Tickets: $150 plus tax and gratuities. (There are two four-and-a-half-hour fireworks cruises that board at 5:30 p.m. and sail from 6:30 to 11 p.m.. One has a sit-down dinner, for $300; the other has a buffet dinner, for $195.) Reservations and information: 212 630-8100.
THE DOROTHY B. VIII, Pier 6, Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. A tall ships parade cruise, 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. Tickets: $100. (Fireworks cruise, 6 p.m. to midnight. Tickets: $100. Information: 718 646-4057.)

J. F. K. FERRY, St. George Ferry Terminal, Staten Island. The National Maritime Historical Society is sponsoring a ride on a retired Staten Island ferry, the John F. Kennedy, which will be cruising near Governors Island. The 1964 boat boards at 7 a.m. Tickets: $150. Information: (914) 737-7878 or at www.seahistory.org.
Best Places for Fireworks Fans To See the Sky Light Up

This year Macy's is calling its annual Fourth of July fireworks display ''Beyond the Dream, a Millennium Celebration.'' More than 60,000 shells will be shot from 12 barges in four harbor locations: the East River, the South Street Seaport, the Hudson River and Brooklyn/Staten Island. The half-hour display begins around 9:30 p.m. and will be broadcast live on Channel 4. Here are the best spots for viewing:

MIDTOWN AT THE EAST RIVER: Any point in Manhattan, Brooklyn or Queens with a clear view over the river between Midtown Manhattan; Hunters Point, Queens; and Greenpoint, Brooklyn. The F.D.R. Drive will be open to pedestrians only beginning at 7 p.m. from 14th to 42nd Streets, with access at 23rd, 38th and 41st Streets; an entrance at 34th Street will be accessible to wheelchairs. Pedestrians will not be allowed on the Queensboro Bridge.

LOWER MANHATTAN AT THE EAST RIVER: In Manhattan, the South Street Seaport; in Brooklyn, the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, Empire Fulton Ferry State Park and Furman Street from Atlantic Avenue to Cadman Plaza West, and points between Joralemon and Cranberry Streets and south of the Brooklyn Bridge. Lower F.D.R. Drive will be open to pedestrians only beginning at 5:30 p.m. from Broad Street to the Brooklyn Bridge, with access from the Brooklyn Bridge/Pearl Street exit ramp and near the Ferry Terminal. No viewing will be allowed from the Brooklyn, Manhattan or Williamsburg Bridges.

STATEN ISLAND/BROOKLYN: In Brooklyn, north of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge along Shore Parkway, between Owl's Head Park and the Brooklyn entrance to the bridge and from Bay Ridge Parkway to 86th Street; on Staten Island, along waterfront areas of Stapleton and Clifton and along Front Street. No viewing allowed from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

THE HUDSON RIVER: Any point in Manhattan and New Jersey with a clear view of the river along the West 40's, including the New Jersey waterfront communities from West New York and Weehawken to northern Hoboken. The West Side Highway will be open to pedestrians only beginning at 5:30 p.m. from 23rd to 57th Streets.

FIREWORKS WATCH ON ROOSEVELT ISLAND. Viewing of the display over the East River from the southern point of the island. Pre-fireworks entertainment begins at 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation. Tickets, $15, are available at the tram stations in Manhattan and on Roosevelt Island as well as at the office of the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation, 591 Main Street, Roosevelt Island. Information: (212) 832-4540, extension 355.

The island can be reached by tram from the station at Second Avenue and 60th Street. (The fare is $1.50 one way; under 5, free.) A free shuttle will transport riders from the tram to Southpoint. From Manhattan, the Queens-bound B or Q trains stop at Roosevelt Island. The island can also be reached by the Q102 bus from Long Island City, Queens, and by car over the 36th Avenue Bridge at 21st Street, Long Island City.
